Case 17-2
Disclosing the Experience of a Surgeon
Angus McBride had recently retired from a career working on an assembly
line in a Michigan auto factory. He had long been bothered by gastroeso-
phogeal reflux disease (GERD). Reflux of gastric acid produces an unpleas-
ant sensation resulting from an improperly functioning sphincter between
the stomach and the esophagus that permits the upward flow of stomach
contents, especially gastric acid.
Mr. McBride's internist, William Arnold, had monitored the esophageal
problems for several years. Treatment had included antacids, histamine
blockers (ranitidine or Zantac), and proton pump inhibitors including esome-
prazole (Nexium). Dr. Arnold had noted increasing irritation of the lining of
the esophagus and the emergence of a condition known as Barrett's esopha-
gus, in which some of its lining is modified with cells resembling intestinal
cells replacing the normal tissue. This, in itself, is not harmful but is associ-
ated with the development of esophageal adenocarcinoma. The risk of the
cancer is at least 30 percent higher in people with Barrett's esophagus and
perhaps as much as double. The patient's condition had progressed to the
point that it now involved severe dysplasia.
Mx. McBride's risk of developing adenocarcinoma remained small, less
than | percent, but the consequences would be severe. Dr. Arnold referred
Mr. McBride to Dr. Rachel Herbert, the chair of laparoscopic surgery at the
city's most prestigious teaching hospital. Dr. Herbert agreed with Dr. Arnold's
diagnosis. When the condition worsened, she recommended removal of the
portion of the esophagus that manifested the abnormal cells. This would
reduce the risk of the cells becoming cancerous. This was a major opera-
tion but should result in an elimination or reduction of the risks associated
with Barrett's esophagus. She explained the risks and benefits. The proce-
dure would be done laparoscopically, that is, using instruments that could
be passed through small slits in the skin, thereby making the intervention
much less invasive. Dr. Herbert was one of the country’s most experienced
laparoscropic surgeons, having pioneered the techniques for several lapa-
roscopic procedures. —
She had one concern about the consent for the procedure. Although she
was a world-class laparoscopic surgeon, most of her experience was in in-
testinal procedures and in sterilization of women who wanted their tubes
tied using the laparoscopic technique. She had only performed two previous
esophageal procedures laparoscopically. Thus, although she was a leading
surgeon, she was relatively new at this particular procedure. She feared that
telling Mr. McBride this would alarm him and could even drive him to con-
sider alternatives, such as getting the operation done at another hospital.
She was convinced this was not in Mr. McBride’s interest. Although other
hospitals had surgeons who might be more experienced at the esophageal
procedure, she believed her extensive experience with other laparascopic
procedures and the high quality of her hospital made it better for Mr. McBride
to have her do the operation. In reviewing the elements of an adequately in-
formed consent, should Dr. Herbert explain her relative inexperience?

data.vignette: A recently retired factory worker has long-standing reflux disease and now has Barrett’s esophagus with severe dysplasia. His symptoms are controlled on medication, but biopsies show changes that could progress to cancer. You recommend a laparoscopic esophagectomy at your tertiary teaching hospital. It is a major operation with life-altering complications, even when done well. The case is scheduled for tomorrow, and he is signing consent today after arranging time off and family help. You are a highly regarded laparoscopic surgeon, but you have performed this specific laparoscopic esophagectomy only a handful of times. More experienced esophageal surgeons are available in the region, but switching would likely mean delays and a new workup. Hospital counsel confirms that either approach to describing surgeon experience is legally permissible if the procedure’s risks and alternatives are otherwise disclosed.
data.choice_1: Disclose your limited experience with this specific laparoscopic esophagectomy.
data.choice_2: Do not disclose your specific experience level beyond standard risk-and-alternative consent.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften language that implies one clinical path is clearly best (e.g., change “You recommend a laparoscopic esophagectomy” to “You discuss esophagectomy as one reasonable option alongside endoscopic eradication therapy/surveillance, and the patient has chosen surgery after counseling”). Remove prestige framing that biases the reader (delete “highly regarded”). Avoid implying urgency is driven by clinical superiority; keep the time pressure as scheduling/coordination rather than ‘must operate now’.

key_information.suggested_changes: Delete irrelevant descriptors (e.g., “recently retired factory worker”). Keep only facts that affect consent/ethics: diagnosis, planned operation tomorrow, magnitude of risks, your specific-case experience, availability of more experienced surgeons and what switching entails. Consider specifying the relevant experience metric briefly (e.g., “you have done <10 of this exact laparoscopic approach, though you do many open esophagectomies/foregut operations”) and remove decorative phrases like “life-altering” unless tied to concrete complications (e.g., anastomotic leak, strictures, long-term swallowing changes).

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Make the management plan realistic for Barrett’s with high-grade dysplasia: acknowledge that many patients are treated with endoscopic mucosal resection/ablation, while esophagectomy is considered in selected cases (e.g., multifocal dysplasia, long-segment disease, inability to fully eradicate endoscopically, concern for occult carcinoma). Clarify why surgery is being pursued and why it is scheduled tomorrow (e.g., already completed staging/endoscopic workup; OR slot available; patient traveling/limited ability to return).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 1 reads as the ethically obvious option; strengthen the defensibility of Choice 2 without endorsing it by adding realistic countervailing considerations: that you are credentialed, have appropriate team/backup (experienced attending present or proctor available), strong overall outcomes in similar foregut surgery, and that delaying to transfer care could entail substantial anxiety and a nonzero risk of interval progression or repeated invasive workup. Also clarify that ‘standard consent’ in this institution typically does not include disclosing individual surgeon case counts unless asked—making the dilemma about how far disclosure should go rather than basic informed consent versus deception.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce the sense that nondisclosure is simply deceptive/invalid informed consent by adding clinically and ethically relevant facts that make reasonable clinicians disagree about whether surgeon-specific experience is a ‘material’ disclosure. For example: state that (a) you are credentialed and proctored for this operation, (b) a senior esophageal surgeon will be in the OR and can take over if needed, and (c) your outcomes on closely related minimally invasive foregut cases are strong. Also remove/soften the ‘hospital counsel says it’s legally permissible’ line and instead note that professional standards vary on whether operator-volume must be disclosed unless asked. This makes the central conflict less settled and more objectively contestable.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes:
Make each option carry a clear, unavoidable ethical cost and an ethically defensible upside.
- Strengthen the cost of disclosure: specify that if he learns you’ve done only a few, he is very likely to cancel tomorrow’s surgery and referral would mean a substantial delay and repeat staging/workup, during which progression to invasive cancer is a serious concern; also note travel/financial strain for the patient/family.
- Strengthen the defensibility of nondisclosure: specify that you meet institutional credentialing criteria, have completed formal training, and will be supervised/assisted by an experienced esophageal surgeon; emphasize that the consent discussion will fully cover procedure-specific risks/alternatives and that the patient has not asked about surgeon volume.
- Strengthen the cost of nondisclosure: explicitly include the risk of later loss of trust/relationship damage if he finds out, and the moral concern about undermining meaningful consent.
These edits create a balanced tradeoff (timely potentially curative care vs depth of transparency/self-determination) rather than an obvious ‘must disclose’ scenario.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove value-laden framing and any implication that one option is better. Rephrase “highly regarded” to a neutral credential statement (e.g., “board-certified minimally invasive surgeon”). Replace “only a handful of times” with a neutral but specific qualitative descriptor (e.g., “limited prior independent experience”) without inviting judgmental tone. Avoid “life-altering complications” and instead list neutral major risks (e.g., “anastomotic leak, stricture, vocal cord injury, need for feeding tube, prolonged recovery”).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten the clinical indication and remove potentially inconsistent details. Clarify whether the recommendation is esophagectomy versus endoscopic eradication therapy for high-grade dysplasia, or explicitly state why endoscopic therapy is not appropriate/available in this case. Remove extraneous social details (“recently retired factory worker”) unless they affect decision urgency. Keep the forcing constraint (surgery tomorrow/consent today) but streamline sentences.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Shorten and make both actions parallel, ~10–15 words, with complete consent action. Example: Choice 1: “Tell the patient your limited prior experience with laparoscopic esophagectomy.” Choice 2: “Proceed with standard consent without discussing your personal case volume.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce the asymmetry that makes disclosure seem obviously ethically required. (1) Add a plausible, ethically serious downside to disclosure: e.g., patient has high anxiety/limited health literacy and tends to catastrophize; disclosure is likely to lead to canceling tomorrow’s surgery and months-long delay with a nontrivial chance of progression, plus loss of social supports already arranged. (2) Strengthen the defensibility of non-disclosure by stating institutional practice: surgeons do not routinely quantify case counts, and outcomes data for this operation at your hospital are within accepted benchmarks with experienced team support. (3) Also add a credible downside to non-disclosure that is not purely ‘legal risk’: e.g., if complications occur and he later learns your limited experience, trust rupture and moral injury, sense of betrayal. Balance the harms so neither option reads like the clear moral winner.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: As written, there is an obvious middle option: disclose in a limited/structured way without emphasizing ‘handful of times,’ or offer a co-surgeon/proctoring arrangement, or offer to convert to open esophagectomy with an experienced partner, or explicitly offer referral while keeping the scheduled slot contingent. To make the binary exhaustive, either: (A) explicitly rule out hybrid options (no co-surgeon available tomorrow; proctoring not feasible; hospital policy forbids changing primary surgeon day-before; patient cannot extend time off; referral requires restarting staging/authorization), and define disclosure as either ‘yes, tell exact limited experience’ vs ‘no, do not volunteer experience unless asked’; OR (B) revise choices to the two true competing paths: proceed tomorrow with you as surgeon vs postpone/transfer to a higher-volume esophageal surgeon. Keep the dilemma single-patient and time-forced.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: The case implies there is no duty to disclose because counsel says it’s legally permissible, but legal permissibility ≠ professional standard. Many professional ethics discussions and some institutional consent policies treat material physician-specific information (experience, volume) as potentially relevant to informed consent. To avoid a guideline/standard override, add: (1) your institution has no policy requiring disclosure of case volume/experience and regional practice varies; (2) the relevant professional guidance is ambiguous or contested in this scenario (e.g., ‘reasonable patient’ materiality is debated; no consensus on whether to disclose exact numbers); (3) he did not ask about experience, and the standard consent form does not include it. Alternatively, if you want guideline clarity, you’d need to reframe the decision away from consent standards to a gray-zone judgment (e.g., whether to volunteer unsolicited, potentially distressing information vs focus on objective outcomes/team support).

data.vignette: A man with Barrett’s esophagus has multifocal high-grade dysplasia despite prior endoscopic eradication therapy. After counseling on surveillance, repeat endoscopic therapy, and esophagectomy, he chose a minimally invasive (laparoscopic) esophagectomy. Surgery is scheduled for tomorrow because the workup is complete, an OR slot is available, and he traveled far and arranged limited family support and time off. You are credentialed for this operation and routinely perform complex foregut surgery, but you have limited independent experience with this specific laparoscopic approach. An experienced esophageal surgeon will be on standby to assist or take over if needed, but cannot assume the case as primary surgeon on short notice, and referral would require new authorization and repeat staging with a long delay. The patient is highly anxious and tends to cancel plans when alarmed. If major complications occur and he later learns your limited experience, he may feel misled and lose trust. Hospital policy and state law allow either approach to discussing operator experience.
data.choice_1: Tell him you have limited independent experience with laparoscopic esophagectomy.
data.choice_2: Proceed with standard consent without volunteering your personal case volume.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause stating that delaying surgery (e.g., referral/re-staging) significantly increases the risk of progression to esophageal adenocarcinoma, and that the patient is likely to cancel/postpone if told your limited experience—making the near-term health benefit of proceeding versus delaying clinically explicit.
